title: Agreement wasn't fulfilled
question: I leased a car,and later on my friend borrowed it from me and said he will take the lease over by the end of summer,because of trust I didn't ask him to give me a written statement that he will take it over ,so now he got two tickets and didn't pay them ,tickets are for parking so they go under my name,one of them went to collection because of it, nor does he pay on time for it,and doesn't reply to my calls, and avoids me,he also excited the limit of mileage I have a year by times, my question is can I force him to take over the lease,or can I at least get the compensation,for all the troubles he made.What is the maximum penalty which can be applied towards him
question_tags: Business contracts,Business insurance,Commercial rental property,Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lease agreements for renting,Business,Small claims court
answers: The other gentlemen are correct. If you're on the lease, you're responsible for it. But, it could be worse. You could've loaned it to these guys. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9n8RNykwXEA

I'm afraid this one goes in the "no good deed goes unpunished" category. I'm confident you will find that your lease language does not allow you to do "just do" what you did with your friend. It must be approved by the folks leasing to you. If you did not do this formally and in writing and with approval of lease company, you are likely on the hook for all of this. You may be able to get some money back, maybe, by suing in small claims court, once you know exactly what the damages are. I'm not confident your insurance, btw, can cover friend and less confident your friend has insurance to cover the vehicle, so, I highly recommend you get that car back fast before more bad things happen...

An agreement to be responsible for the contract or debts of another party requires a signed writing by your friend (the guarantor). To take over the lease would require the leasing company to agree in writing to transfer the agreement to your friend and release you from responsibility. Even if your friend now signs a guarantee, that does not mean the leasing company will agree to transfer the obligation to your friend, as they will want to see if your friend has good credit and steady income, otherwise you remain liable for the full lease, including any late payments.

Because the lease you wanted your friend to take over is for more than a year and it involves a vehicle worth over $500, so it must be in writing to conform with the statute of frauds. Thus, it is doubtful that you can force him to take over the lease or sue him for your damages. You trusted this person with your leased car and your credit, without anything in writing. When he turns in the car (hopefully) at lease termination, not only will they charge you for the excess mileage, but for all damage and excess "wear and tear." I don't know that you will be able to win a case against him. Perhaps another attorney on Avvo will have suggestions on how to prevail on such claims for an oral agreement.
